case_title: Mst. BIBI LAL BIBI vs MIR BALUCH KHAN AND Another

accussed_details.name: Nawab Habibullah Khan
allegation: Dispute over partition of ancestral property

complaint_summary: The appellant filed a suit for partition of movable and immovable property left by her ancestor, Sardar Nauroze Khan, against her nephew, Nawab Habibullah Khan. The claim was initially dismissed due to vagueness.
investigation_summary: The property dispute involved ancestral assets left by Sardar Nauroze Khan and Sardar Yaqoob Khan. The case was remanded multiple times for evidence collection and clarification of claims.
judgment_summary: The Balochistan High Court restored the decree of the Kazi of Kharan, which ordered the partition of immovable property among the heirs of Sardar Nauroze Khan and Sardar Yaqoob Khan. The court set aside the Majlis-i-Shura's decision to remand the case for further evidence, citing sufficient proof already presented.
Decision_or_verdict: Appeals allowed; decree restored for partition of immovable property.
legal_arguments: The Kazi's judgment was based on sufficient documentary evidence, including the settlement deed of 1883.
Ex parte proceedings were justified due to the absence of defendants.
The Majlis-i-Shura erred in remanding the case despite adequate evidence.
assets: Landed property left by Sardar Nauroze Khan and Sardar Yaqoob Khan
Properties awarded as blood money by Shahi Jirga
sections: Section 86 of Interim Constitution of Baluchistan States Union, 1952
Section 86 of Pakistan Civil Procedure Code, 1908
citations: F. Kanematsu & Co. Ltd. v. S. Nazir Hussain Puri (P L D 1957 Kar. 832)

witness_statement.Amir Muhammad Khan: Testified regarding the settlement deed and ancestral property details.
witness_statement.Mir Ibrahim Khan: Provided evidence supporting the claim for partition.
witness_statement.Nawabzada Shahbaz Khan: Confirmed maintenance allowances received in lieu of property shares.

key_issues: Validity of Kazi's judgment based on ex parte proceedings
Sufficiency of evidence for partition decree
Applicability of section 86 of Interim Constitution

maxims.Ex parte proceedings: A court must ensure prima facie proof before passing an ex parte decree.

legal_terms.Partition decree: A judicial order dividing property among rightful heirs.
legal_terms.Ex parte: Proceedings conducted in the absence of one party.

words_and_phrases.Mianji Khana: Management of property under a state-appointed receiver.
words_and_phrases.Blood money: Compensation awarded for a murder under tribal or customary law.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around the partition of ancestral property among heirs of Sardar Nauroze Khan and Sardar Yaqoob Khan. The High Court restored the Kazi's decree, rejecting the Majlis-i-Shura's remand order. Key evidence included the 1883 settlement deed and oral testimonies. Ex parte proceedings were deemed valid due to the absence of defendants.

key_points.dispute: Partition of landed property left by Sardar Nauroze Khan and Sardar Yaqoob Khan
key_points.initial_suit: Filed by Bibi Lal Bibi on 1953-10-08
key_points.appeal_remand: Majlis-e-Shura remanded case to Kazi for decision on merits
key_points.kazi_decision: Partition decree for immovable property passed on 1959-04-18
key_points.majlis_shura_decision: Set aside Kazi's decree and remanded for further evidence
key_points.final_court_decision: Restored Kazi's decree and set aside Majlis-e-Shura's order

legal_provisions.interim_constitution: Section 86 of Interim Constitution of Baluchistan States Union, 1952
legal_provisions.civil_procedure_code: Section 86 of Pakistan Civil Procedure Code, 1908

partition_details.property_source: Settlement deed of 1883 by Sardar Azad Khan
partition_details.excluded_properties: Gifted properties or those given in lieu of shares
